comments.commentBody: Slipped in among his many gaffes was one comment not getting enough play. Donald Trump suggested that Hillary Clinton would not be taken seriously if negotiating with countries like Saudi Arabia. Not only was his comment ignorant of the realities, it was also grossly misogynistic and disqualifying in my opinion. A comment like that implies no woman can be president.

The Know Nothing Party got the Ignoramus nominee it was praying for and he failed his first Presidential test with flying colors due to a nasty bout of overconfidence, lack of curiosity, lack of knowledge, lack of temperament and a complete lack of preparation.

The winner, by Technical Knock Out, Madam Secretary Clinton.

Donald Trump will now go back to the Snake Oil Sales Room and whip up a fresh batch of lies for the Grand Old Prevaricating faithful who are religiously counting on him to lie and insult his way to Presidential stardom.

Trump will return another day to fight for that great noble American and Assimovian principle that 'my ignorance is just as good as your knowledge'.

Well done, Madam...well done.

This was a pretty decent outcome for those who are sane.

Like all bullies, Trump folded like a cheap lawn chair when confronted with someone strong. Between this performance and standing there mute with his head bowed next to the President of Mexico, kind of makes you wonder about his claims of being a tough guy and relentless negotiator.

I will be very surprised if he shows up at another debate - he's clearly not capable of coherent, rational discourse.

Hilariously, Fox News is applauding his performance as a winning one.

The debate was mixed.  The first 20 minutes went to Trump.  The last hour or 45 minutes went o Clinton.  So that means if you have trouble focusing you could very well feel that Trump was winning then turn away satisfied.  If you wanted o savor every moment of the program then you would see the momentum shift to Clinton.  I don't think these debates will change anyone's minds.  One of them needs to find a new way to present their message.

It takes a special type of person to turn a 90 minute debate all about himself, practically reading his falsified resume to the class. My friend's 13 year old was even disgusted... And she & I both lean toward the Republican Party during a 'normal' year.

It's a sad state of affairs when the circus this evening is giving us a preview of just how far this country has fallen. As someone who holds dual citizenship, believe me when I say Trump is not going to 'make America great again.' Nor will Hillary Clinton. Why? Because just like Pres. Obama in 2008, our next president is inheriting a mess & a fractured country.

If you truly want America to be great again, the first step is simple, yet uncomfortable for most Americans: they need to admit that it's not great. It's not #1. And that's not a new development. History has begun to show the effects of policies implemented by Reagan, especially in California. None of this happened overnight.

Is Hillary corrupt? Yep. Am I voting for her in the end? Begrudgingly. I may not like her, but Donald Trump should not be anywhere near the White House. Take the name Trump & replace it with 'Palin'... It's simply a louder, far more orange, & equally crazy version of the same costume.

Has anything happened in a presidential debate quite as astounding as one of the candidates bragging that not paying federal income taxes makes him smart? Amidst the incoherence, defensiveness, and rudeness, that moment stands out as being truly shocking. How perplexing that this man wants to lead a government while proudly scorning one of the most basic things that allow that government to function.

And how STUPID. How confusingly, unprofessionally STUPID. That's the thing that I can't wrap my mind around. Far from a nefarious conman, he is so foolish as to walk right into a trap and then, in a fit of anger, to blurt something so inconvenient and counterproductive. How did we get to this point?

Donald Trump needs a teleprompter for life, not just a presidential campaign.  It was a mostly classic unscripted Trump on display for the last two thirds of the debate. However, he did appear more flustered than usual.  The Marco Rubio-like frequent hydration moments revealed a Trump that looked uncommonly nervous and ill prepared  when he wasn't hearing his own voice drowning out both Clinton and the moderator.

Trump's loss is a big deal.  Ever since Obama toasted his tootsies at the White House Correspondents Dinner in 2011, The Donald has been on a quest to be Taken Seriously by People Who Matter.  As tonight's debate demonstrated, he just doesn't have what it takes.  He can still wow the crowds at his rallies -- maybe yet garner enough votes to be president (Please, God, NO!) -- but he's a punchline in search of a joke, and always will be.

Donald Trump used the word "unbelievable" countless times in his arguemtns tonight without realizing the self-reference many of us surely felt.

Imagine, Donald Trump complaining about not being treated nicely by a woman he recently described as "the Devil".

Honestly, the only word I would use to describe Trump tonight -- his arguments, his logic, his appearance, and his command of policy issues -- is "weak". Likely the last thing Trump and his supporters want to be seen as. Yet, there it was for all to see. Unbelievable.

Despite trying several times, Holt seemed powerless to moderate Trump's repeated loud, brash, almost incoherent intrusions while Clinton was speaking. She kept to the time allocated her; Trump seized as much time as he wanted.

On the one hand, she was happy to have Trump intrude and shout her down. Not only did it reveal him as a bully, but as it turned out he used the extra time to dig a bigger hole for himself. One pundit later lamented that Clinton didn't hit back hard enough. The reality, of course, is that Clinton would have been roundly condemned had she done so. Given the double standard that has permeated this campaign, voters would have penalized Clinton for being too aggressive or unladylike had she followed Trump's lead.

The bullying was all one sided; she didn't interrupt him at all while he shouted her down 26 times by one account. Holt - and the moderators who will follow him - might have considered the option of killing the mike of whichever candidate shouts down the other or goes beyond the allotted time.

This was just surreal.

If self-medicating works the proof it can be found in Trump's deflated fans who proclaim his victory.

My mom -- almost 100 now -- is Chinese from a generation taught to defer to men and view unfavorably women who achieve prominence. In her mind and from her culture there's a natural order and women aren't part of it. That's despite her degree from St. John's University in Shanghai, regarded as the "Harvard of China." Despite being a single immigrant woman, raising two sons while employed as a translator and journalist at Chinese publications where she was the only woman.

By virtue of his gender alone Trump would win my mom's support. I watched tonight with her. She smiled when Trump talked and knitted her brow when Hillary spoke. Five minutes in, when Trump grew obnoxious, my mother began to look irritated and soon contemptuous. "What kind of man is he? He is insults his parents with his behavior. He humiliates them with such low class manners."

Hillary? Maybe it was her lucky (for Chinese) red pantsuit but "This is an educated woman from a good family. You can see that in the proper way she speaks and her bravery to speak forcefully to that man. I feel sorry for that man's wife but she must be a stupid girl to have married him."

Trump had my mom by default. In 90 minutes he broke 100 years of deeply ingrained male bias. At her age she uses an absentee ballot. After the "debate" she went looking for it. She had seen and heard enough.

A college friend and I have the same fear, that Trump might actually win.  We live  hundreds of miles from each other, but both of us can feel the fear.  Hillary Clinton helped assuage that fear for me tonight.  She is presidential and experienced.  I believe that she will win this election.  The vast majority of those that will vote for Trump are white men who feel that their extreme power is being eroded.  It is, and even a Trump victory (gulp) won't change that.  This is the wonderful USA.  We have always been a country that accepted immigrants and we always will.  I am proud of that.  I love to say I am an American.  I really do.

From the moment the split screen revealed the two candidates' faces, I felt instinctively that Trump was going to have a rough night. His scowling, squinting and fidgeting demeanor presaged his scrambled egg gibberish at the end of this spectacle. Richard Nixon looked Mt. Rushmore ready, compared to this era's crass Republican. Instead of Nixon's telltale sweat beads, Trump performed a symphony of sniffs and snorts. (Did he catch Hillary's pneumonia backstage?)

When Trump proclaimed, to muffled audience guffaws, his superior temperament, his goose was cooked, dried and filleted. The post debate question of the moment is does he have the stamina to do it again?

I'm sure many of his supporters would rather watch a mud wrestling match between Sean Hannity and Rosie O'Donnell. Now that would be entertaining, although no more enlightening of Trump's command of governance.

It amazes me that people in the US overwhelmingly would NOT lend money to this guy, rightly so after four bankruptcies, but would give him the key to the oval office and a chance to influence their future and the future of their children....

Trump did not have the "stamina" and did not "look presidential".  He deteriorated as the night went on to a point of blithering and inarticulate confusion.  His candidacy reflects profoundly on the utter deterioration of the republican party.  It wasn't even close.  He knows nothing and cares only for himself and his money, which he mentioned many times, and would bring great economic and social destruction to our country if elected.

Watching the Debate last evening was like attending a revival of 'Death of A Salesman' with Trump in trouble, representing the Voice of Downtrodden America.

Some of us may not get out of the aftermath of this Recession, but we can try by extending help to others if able and fit. Trump left us with no solutions. We do not have a Republican nominee. The road ahead is filled with obstacles, and this American is renewing my pledge to support the Democrat Nominee, Hillary Clinton.

Special thanks to Leslie Holt, a fine American voice and a professional. Hoping the New York Times will continue to ask its Readership for questions that Commentators may have for the next Presidential Debate.

Actually, we need to set aside the debate theatrics from last night.

Yes, Donald Trump was a disastrous debater. He was unprepared, thin-skinned, non credible, argumentative and insulting.

But that's not the real issue.

The real issue is to picture him negotiating with Vladimir Putin or XI Jinping on any matter of substance wherein the national credibility and best interests are manifest on all sides.

Think about it.

Can even the staunchest republican voter out there really believe that Trump is the person our country would want to best represent us as a people?

He brought up Rosie O'Donnell in the debate. Rosie O'Donnell. He had 90 minutes to speak to Americans (and much of the world) about his plan for our future prosperity, and he brought up Rosie O'Donnell. What a joke.

I caught Trump making a few salient points in the beginning there. But he quickly recalibrated to himself.

There is nothing he can say on the birther issue short of an apology. But he chooses to say how proud he is of himself for his efforts in "proving" that the Obama is a US citizen. That it never occurs to him how shameful and utterly insulting his actions were is why he can't recover with most black people. Over 40 presidents, none were hounded to produce a birth certificate to prove his citizenship. Yet, he feels he "did a good job" in laying the issue to rest. Why was there ever an issue? That's the fundamental question.

Trump really is not prepared for the job. I felt sorry seeing him standing there just repeating the same old sound bites and how he will make things great again, all the while making all sorts of crazy faces and looking like he was ready to melt down. Clinton had some plans that sounded like they could work and some that were just a mix of the right words. Trying to fix race relations here and ISIS in the world is just about impossible, however I feel better giving her a chance.

Trump's acolytes cried foul by claiming Hillary spent the last two weeks preparing for the debate and he didn't. I'm a college instructor. When I administer an exam it is implied that students who prepare succeed and those who don't prepare fail. The debate is an exam. Hillary prepared and succeeded. The flippant and lazy Trump thought he could simply think on his feet and win the night. You can bet that his team is now imploring him to do what he failed to do last night. I am confident he will continue to ignore their pleas and remain shallow and ignorant.

I thought that Donald Trump's performance in the first "debate" last night was proof positive that the articles I have seen over the last week or so regarding his debate prep were correct. Apparently, he has spent his time working on his sneer, his eye-rolling and his interrupting skills. He did not come prepared to make an argument supported by facts but rather he continued to haul out the same tropes that have been fact-checked and debunked over and over since he announced his candidacy.

It's not easy to spell out a detailed platform position in this kind of format and I wish that the media, particularly television, would do more to probe each candidates' positions and program proposals. Maybe instead of more of this "debates" the network pool could devote 90 minutes to Trump and Clinton individually, with real journalists asking detailed questions and demanding detailed answers. That is a program that I would watch.

Finally - I'm a Republican and was going to vote for HRC anyway but last night's performance convinced me that there is no way we can afford - in any sense - a Trump presidency.

In watching televised debate in other countries (Britain, Canada), it is a rare thing to hear one speaker being interrupted and allowed to talk across the other, rudely stepping over the other's allotted time. Unfortunately, most debate in the United States, from commentary panels to last night's national debate is marred by the propensity - and now commonplace- of a verbal brawl with interruption and word-climbing over top of one another.

I would like to suggest a remedy: at the outset, let it be known that anyone speaking out of turn will have their mic cut off, and the cumulative time when their lips are seen moving will be taken from them and granted to the other party to use freely and fully at the end of the debate.

Used during last night's debate, Trump would have surrendered a significant portion of time, which he had in any case attempted to steal from Clinton with his interjections and rudeness. The face smirks, twitches and glowering evidenced in the split screen revealed a great deal of his true character, which people can well judge for themselves in the silence.

I've read comments criticizing Lester Holt, which I find surprising.  Holt is a professional and a gentleman.  Since he was not armed with a Taser, baseball bat, or other suitable equipment, there was no way he could shut Donald Trump up when he was interrupting without completely disrupting the proceedings.  So let's demand that this is done electronically in future debates, and let each candidate have all of their allotted time.

Very disappointed when Lester Holt asked the candidates about the proposed changes to the "first use" of nuclear weapons policy, that he completely let Trump off the hook. Trump flat out skirted the question with a rambling diatribe on "nuclear" this and that and then criticized Clinton and Obama on climate change.

If anything could have exposed Trump's lack of depth it would have been how he answered the question, as it would have required some explanation of how the purported use of nuclear weapons serves as a deterrent and is the foundation of our national security.

Reading the press this morning, no one seemed to notice -- a very sad and sorry commentary on the superficial and vacuous state of the political dialogue in our country.
